Here I am, back before the window of my study in Bramley.
I returned to lovely weather, the kind we counted on when we
rented this place in Surrey, and the kind of weather that
makes us wish this were the beginning of our first month here,
rather than the end of the eighth!
Berlin was interesting: interesting in itself; for its
two political divisions; and for its importance in the news.
I toured both sections, took many pictures in both (to
document the Incredible difference between the eastern and
western sectors); and recorded an interview with two of the
top people in Bias. This should have reached KUOM by now.
It is available to any and all interested NAEB stations.
My line was: last night in my hotel I listened to radio
programs from all sidesâ€”Rias, west Berlin, east Berlin,
west Germany, east Germany, BBC, French, AFN, Polish, VGA
and Moscow; what are the reasons for all these services, what
differences are there in the programs, and especially, what
is the purpose of RIAS.
In Hamburg I talked to Walter Schultz, In charge of
foreign contacts for Norddeutche Rundfunk. (He, of course,
speaks only for radio in Northern Germany; there are some six
or seven other German networks, each as independent as
American local stations on the same network.; I asked about
supplying programs to NAEB. Yes, this was being done through
Seymour Siegel and BFA. What about some extra programs. Yes,
they recently sent an opera by R. Strauss; it was sent to
NAEB-WNYC-BFA: he seemed to lump us all together. I tried
to explain, but he was less patient than the Swedes.
He did make one point of interest, though. They have
no problem getting permission from musicians to distribute
tapes of major musical performances. Their musical schedule
is superb: I heard their symphony orchestra, and it Is
first rate. When they do premieres and works commissioned
for them, they like extra performances In the States. The
person to contact here is: Walter D. Schultz, Norddeutscher
Rundfunk, Rothenbaumchaussee 132-134, Hamburg 13.
